poem:
Title: Drawing Lines on Sand

Netanyahu's breath laces order of clash,
For Rafah, city bearing the burden of displacement.
Echoes tremble across the globe in flash,
Worrisome whispers of further disengagement.

Yet, in the predictability of chaos,
Akin to forces meeting with brutish power,
Children of the same Mother turn foes,
Beneath the shadow of a looming tower.

A bitter requiem, Gaza's crisis,
Humanity's frailty laid bare, no disguises.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Netanyahu approves plans for Rafah attack, Israeli officials say Benjamin Netanyahu has approved plans for an attack on Rafah, the southernmost city in Gaza where more than a million people displaced from elsewhere in the territory have sought shelter, officials in Israel have said. The decision will provoke deep concern around the world. Any attack on the city is likely to cause significant civilian casualties and worsen an already acute humanitarian crisis across the territory.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
